38643797.review:
Kingsway is an amazing game in nearly every regard, but with one fatal flaw that hinders the experience quite a bit. You begin Kingsway just like any other RPG game, create your character, pick a class, and get thrown into the game with limited tutorials so that you can figure it out on your own. It was actually very easy to pick up and play, and the operating system aesthetic of the game allows players to have the game layout be however they want. It basically offered a whole new level of player choice that I found really enjoyable. Onto the actual gameplay itself. You select areas on the map you want to travel to and as your character moves, you run into various monsters that you will have to fight. Monsters can drop loot upon defeating them that the player can use to their advantage, or just become a horder. But the amount of random loot frops, weapons, and skills that the player can obtain guarantees that you will have a different experience with every playthrough. The world is also randomized so the player will also be met with new dungeons, maps, and possibilities with every new character they make. It makes it hard to develop a strategy, which just gives it that much more replay value.

So lets just quick run through the pros:
-Amazing user interface
-Infinite replay value
-Easy to pick up
-Genuinely fun
-Player gets to choose how they want to play

But now lets talk about the fatal flaw I mentioned, and that is that the game is not infinite, and you can not keep using the same character forever. The game is set on a small island and the player must move from the left side of the island to the right in order to avoid an evil shadow monster that is set to cover the world in darkness. At the end of the island lies the final boss, where *SPOILER ALERT* the player sacrifices themself to defeat the shadow monster. Your character dies, and this game does have permadeath, so thats where the game ends, and you can decide there to either make a new character or just quit. I would have loved the option to have an infinite world and carry my character up trhough level 100 and fight insanely difficult monsters, and be able to grind for EXP and go on quests. But sadly the game will foce you to face the final boss anywhere from 2 - 4 hours into the game, and then you either die, or win and also die. I just completed the game for the first time after 11 attempts and I dont know if I can play it again knowing I already experienced everything this game has to offer. Let me make this clear, the game really only has one story that you just repeat over and over again. It was a fun ride but now the ride is just over, and I dont even have my character to show for it.

8/10

38638374.review:
Kingsway is a rogue-light, You're a fantasy adventurer who has to travel the lands, light the beacons, and get to the king's castle. Its main gimmick is that the entire game is reminiscent of the win98/95 era in terms of interface. 

Your bags are windows and icons on the desktop, enemies sometimes shoot projectiles in the forms of popups you have to close before they hit you, the enemies themselves sort of drift around the screen at times.  The playable classes are pretty similiar, and even share a bunch of skills between them.  The gameplay isn't bad, it's just lacking in any sort of depth.

 They hit upon a wonderful premise of a classic windows style operating system to play the game in, and then barely do anything with it. Oh, one enemy minimizes your windows, great. A few enemies place a couple of annoying popups on your screen. It's so restrained with its gimmicks that after the first hour or so none of them have any impact on you. Compared to undertale, which took its "dodge'em up lite bullet hell" concept and explored plenty of different attack patterns and silly gimmicks, Kingsway doesn't. And without its gimmicks it's a terribly boring and snore inducing roguelite.  


TL;DR Kingsway is a wonderful concept that isn't utilized at all, leading you to play a boring click attack simulator.

38476426.review:
Kingsway is a roguelike RPG controlled through a user interface that heavily evokes Windows 95. If you're not familiar with those genres, this means that there is permadeath, and the crux of the game is managing resources against a timer (in Kingsway's case, the arrival of a Galactus-style world eating alien known as The Sky Eater) rather than plot. 

The main genius of the game is the user interface. If you've used a PC for any period of time, it'll be pretty immediately intuitive how to do things. It's a game that barely needs to tutorialize because you're already on a PC.

The classes also do a fantastic job of feeling different from each other, and having multiple viable builds. My glass cannon mage ripped through everything before getting hit, while my adventurer focused on shields and slow, strong attacks, nullifying all damage before killing things in a few, big hits. There's no doubt in my mind I could have pushed them (or the other classes I've played) in multiple viable directions, and it's tons of fun experimenting, figuring out what works, then taking a honed build to absolutely murder things.

The one thing I'd caution people on is if you're a roguelike diehard it might be slightly easy for you. I've only got a dozen hours of experience, and I feel like at this point if I can get established in the first fifteen minutes I'm making it to endgame. I haven't done a ton of experimentation yet with the Ring of Pain starting item (which tooltips denote as a hard mode), so that might ratchet up the difficulty. Even so, I think that the user interface and really great class design is a good enough hook to get a few dozen hours of enjoyment out of this. For 10 bucks? That's rock solid.

38070572.review:
Well, who knew presenting a game as a dated operating system would be oodles of fun?

Kingsway is a roguelike RPG that follows the usual mantra -- pick a class, beat up baddies, save the world -- with the twist that everything happens in its own window. So, you have your world view in one screen, your inventory in another, enemies in a screen that bobs and weaves, and traps that zoom across with a flashing AVOID button just a clickk away.

It sounds weird. It plays beautifully. Toss in unlockable classes, multiple endings and a few other "just one more run" tidbits and you have the recipe for a truly remarkable indi gem. Go get it.

38018802.review:
TL;DR: Interesting game, good to try out, but is easy and gets a bit stale relatively fast. Good as an indie game, but don't expect too much.
My review is a bit harsh, I'll admit it, but the game isn't bad. It's just that I hyped too much and expected much more of it. My first run was a blast, if you only want to try out you'll have lots of fun. But if you want more, don't expect much for now.

I'll be honest, Kingsway looks more like a self-made project you'd do for your early portfolios than a real, finished game. I've still liked it so I'll recommend it anyway.

First of all, don't be fooled by my big play time. 40% of it is time spent AFK/alt-tabbed but with the game opened, and a good chunk was me testing the limits of the game. I maybe got 15 hours of real gameplay, though I would've been done much faster if I didn't go for 100%.

So, the game is buggy. Are those gamebreaking bugs that make it impossible to play? No, but they're annoying when you notice them.

Passive effects don't stack. I had the Keen skill (+1 stats on lvlup) and got another one from a boss gear. Didn't get my promised 5 points each level, still 4. Haven't made the maths on Bandage, but I didn't seem to heal much with two of it either.
You can enchant and disenchant items infinitely, but if you leave the game with an enchanted item it'll get stuck when you come back: you'll be able to disenchant it, but not enchant it back (its name won't change either when you disenchant).
Skill books will tell you if you can't learn a skill of if you already know the level 5, but for skills that have only one level the books will get consumed for no benefit.
Ending #5 didn't give me the Beastkin End achievement, though I did it as Beastkin.
I'm probably forgetting some more.

There are design choices I disagree with.
Many items give you a very vague description. I still have no idea what Lucky Coin is supposed to do, I barely used Potion of Attack until I found out the only drawback for overconsumption was poison (drink them all, antidote, poof)
Some items have no purpose... at all. I still have no idea what I'm supposed to do with these Strange Rubble and Horns, all I'm told is that "someone may want this"
Nowhere in the game are you told how to get a Full Rune. It's not that complicated, but it's near impossible to do anyway. I cleared all caves each run, and I regularly stocked up on one or two runes, getting sometimes a third as well. But all 4? Good luck.
You find healing wells in which you can drop and pick up coins. One at a time. What it does is cool, but without a touchpad to go faster it's horrible.
You can find level 11-13 gear on mobs level 5. With bags so limited in size, not very useful.
Enchanting an item increases its level requirement by 1. If you keep disenchanting and re-enchanting an item, it will eventually require a level you can't even reach (you usually reach level 20 but an item can ask hundreds, see my screenshots). And the bonuses aren't scaling with level, a level 1 ring can be enchanted to require level 20 and still be a crappy +1 str.
Skill speed don't make sense. Two skills with the same shown speed have clearly different cast speeds, like Black Fireball and Astral Storm : both are "Very Slow", but AS is like 3 or 4 times faster than BF.
Agility is worthless, I spent like 90% of my points into it and I wasn't much faster than monsters. My Mage with 3 Agility was just as fast.
The only scrolls that have a noticeable effect are the healing scrolls, in combat the time to use them you're likely to miss an attack. They're just not worth it.

Finally, the game is fairly easy. If you can survive through the first two or three levels you're almost sure to go to the end. Gold is an issue very early, but you quickly get flooded with it and you can't even spend it all unless you keep hopping between shops to buy stuff. The hardest part is managing weight, because I'm a hoarder, but the extra gold isn't very impactful.
You can go all the way with only the basic attack and a heal spell (if you can learn it or find a book), I've even leveled up my MAGE by bashing people manually (even though all my stat points were put in intel), and only switched to spells when I got a high level Black Fireball (that got quicly replaced when I found a book of Astral Storm). All you have to do is put your first few stat points in strength to double your damage. The special pop-up attacks are not a big deal, even if you don't put any point in agility. Really, I died only twice during my runs: when I wasn't paying attention at all, and when I tried hard mode with the weakest class (two bandits when you deal 0 damage as first battle isn't easy).

37977186.review:
This game goes hard after Windows 95 nostalgia (if that's a thing?) and absolutely nails it. It's a pretty basic RPG style game where you have to travel around a world lighting 3 beacons to unlock an end boss. There are 4 different classes with different abilities and spells available to learn but I'm not really that sure about the variety because, despite there being permadeath, I actually finished the game with my second character and I'm not feeling the desire to replay the game for a few reasons.

The aesthetic is just really cool and fits with the game's mechanics really well. Your character sheet, the world map and bags are all just icons on the desktop that you open up and can move around and resize at your will, which is actually important because space management on the screen and clutter became a bit of an issue. Things like travel time and attack timers are all loading bars, and the combat is real time and uses the windows in pretty interesting ways. Each enemy opens a new pop-up window and moves around the screen slowly outside of your control while you're clicking on buttons in the window to execute the combat. Some monsters have special abilities that fuck around with this too, there's a shadow bandit who occasionally uses his turn to minimise his window so he's just attacking in the background while you're frantically trying to get the combat back open. Some monsters shoot arrows that are a small window with a "dodge" button on that fly across your screen from right to left and there are a small number of other spells that use a variety of moving windows with dodge buttons. The issue with combat is that everything is great fun and makes you panic the first time you see it but then extremely quickly becomes 2nd nature which reduces the combat to spamming the attack button over and over with minor breaks. You also see all of the different in combat effects early on and after that just meet stronger versions of the same monsters so it really doesn't develop in a way I thought it could after seeing the cool things it was doing in the first 30 minutes, almost as if they ran out of ideas.

The game took 3 hours to finish, across both characters, so it's very short. That actually turns out to be a bit of a blessing because it was getting very repetitive for me already. The most frustrating part is that the final area of the game is absolutely full of random encounters with absolutely no variety. None of the enemies cast spells forcing you to react or do anything interesting with your windows, so you just spam attack until they die and move on to the next irritatingly frequent random encounter. There are a load of unlocks that carry across characters such as health boosts or starting items so I guess they want you to replay the game multiple times but I have no interest in playing it again, it's looks alone are what got me to finish the first run. It's a really neat game and I'd definitely check out a future Kingsway 2 but the first iteration falls short in a few places for me. 6/10

37966527.review:
I have not been able to stop playing this game. Someone please help me.

This is a rogue-esque game with randomly generated worlds and dungeons and is full of quests and events. When I first saw this in a gamestop magazine and saw it was in development phase, I knew I wanted this game. And I don't regret purchasing it one bit. The game has incredible replay value and many interesting events to keep you busy. 

Each play session lasts around 2-4 hours, I even one time spent nearly 5 hours on one. Luckily you are able to save the game and come back to it, but I usually forget where I am and what was happening when I do that.

Many people complain about the "time-limit" aspect, but I could care less for it. It only gives me further reason to keep playing and not simply get lost in the overworld. It encourages thoughtful decision making and conserving time, but I do understand that some people simply aren't a fan of that.

This is your classic RPG style game with leveling up, big bosses, quests and so on. The 5 different endings and extra classes also give you much to play for, I've played for 38 hours so far and only managed one ending. I'm awful at this game but I love it.

37834393.review:
게임 자체는 적당히 재밌음. 근데 컨텐츠가 심하게 모자람. 정가로도 사지 말고 세일을 해도 사지 마셈.

난 아무런 정보도 없이 혼자서 맨땅에 헤딩하면서 시작했고, 처음 두 시간 정도는 별의 별 삽질을 했음. 여관비가 싸서 하루종일 드르렁 하면서 있다가 그림자들한테 썰리고, 그 다음에는 신나게 파밍을 하고 18렙 찍고나서 그림자들을 사냥하다가 체력 9999 스카이 이터랑 만나서 죽고, 그 다음은 쪼렙 때 부터 던전에 들어가서 파밍하려다가 금새 썰리고, 로그라이크의 본질인 죽으면서 배우는 과정이 정말 즐거웠음.


근데, 그 시간은 정말 짧았음.
스카이 이터가 그림자를 드리우는 시간은 정말, 정말, 정말로 느림. 파밍 다 하고 퀘스트 다 하고 특수 몬스터도 다 잡으면서 휘바휘바 춤을 춰도 시간일 남을 정도라서 게임의 난이도가 정말 낮음. 플레이타임이 5시간 정도가 되었을 때 처음으로 클리어하고, 플탐 10시간 찍을 때 까지 두 번을 더 클리어했음. 여타 로그라이크와는 다르게 침착하게 게임을 하면 클리어는 거의 확정적일 정도로 쉬워서 도전욕구가 생기질 않음. 게임을 할 때 마주치는 난관은 아슬아슬하게 넘을 수 있을 정도일 때에 가장 멋진데, 이건 걍 발목까지만 오는 나무뿌리급이라 할 맛이 안 남.

직업별로 게임하는 방식이 완전히 똑같음. 상대보다 먼저 움직여서 적은 피해로 조지는게 끝임. 스킬이야 다른걸 찍는다고 해도 결국 만나서 패고 패고 패고 패서 죽일 뿐이니까 전략성이 쥐뿔도 없음. 그래서 하나의 직업을 다양한 방식으로 플레이하기는 커녕, 여러가지 직업조차 하나의 방식으로 플레이하게 됨.

거기다가 몬스터들의 패턴도 다 똑같음. 굴을 판다, 느린데 스턴을 건다, 마법을 쏜다 등의 특징을 넣은 건 구색은 좋음. 하지만 실제로 게임을 해 보면 내가 상대보다 빠르니까 먼저 패고 방어, 내가 상대보다 많이 빠르면 두대 패고 방어만 반복하게 됨. 몬스터가 쏘는 마법은 많아봤자 한 놈당 두개라고 보면 됨. 마법이 없는 몬스터도 많고, 마법을 쓰는 몬스터 대다수는 마법이 하나임. 몬스터별로 상대법이 다르면 전투가 즐겁기라도 할 건데, 아무것도 달라질 것 없이 원패턴으로 상대할 수 밖에 없음.

아이템 파밍이 흥겹지도 않음. 커먼 아이템이 쏟아지고, 운이 좋으면 매직 아이템이 나오고, 한 게임 전체에 5개 전후로 유니크 아이템이 나오기도 하는데, 아이템 테이블이 랜덤임. 전사인데 방어력 1짜리 텔레포트 셔츠나, 지능제한 19의 오브같은게 자주 나옴. 유니크 아이템이 필요할 정도로 난이도가 높지는 않은데, 그렇다고해서 파밍을 이렇게 재미없게 만들 필요는 있었나 싶음. 몇 번 하면 대충 어떻게 될지 다 보여서 질림.

캐릭터 성장도 오지게 재미없음. 스탯을 찍는 다양성은 없다고 보면 됨. 걍 없음. 직업별로 필요한 스탯이 달라서, 걍 자신에게 맞는 스탯에 몰빵을 하면 됨. 전사같은 경우에는 힘스탯에 90% 정도를 밀어넣으면 되고, 아니면 걍 100% 밀어넣고 지능은 템으로 보충하면 됨. 스킬도 효율이 좋은 것과 나쁜 것의 차이가 극명하게 갈려서 몇 번 하면 결국 원패턴으로 가게 됨. 전사로 러시나 배틀크라이를 주력으로 사용하는 사람은 없을거임.

,
다시 한 번 정리하자면, 컨텐츠가 심각하게 부족해서 금새 질리는 게임임.

다른 사람들 평가를 봐도 이 게임을 오래오래 한 사람은 없을거임. 보통 로그라이크게임에 꽂히면 수백 시간, 수천 시간을 하는 사람도 많음. 돌죽같은 하드한 게임이 아니라도 편도용사, FTL, 던전 오브 디 엔드리스, 네크로댄서 같은 게임을 봐도 킹스웨이보다는 몇 배, 몇십 배를 하고 있음. 여기 평가 남긴 사람들의 플레이타임을 봐도 아마 그럴거임.

파밍의 깊이 얕고, 캐릭터 성장의 폭이 좁고, 난이도가 너무 쉽고, 전투가 심하게 단조로움.
딱 5시간 정도는 재밌게 할 수 있을테니 80% 세일쯤 하면 살지 말지 고려해든가, 아니면 걍 거르던가.

　我々美クソゲー家の間では最近のローグライクゲームの微妙さ加減にイラついていたが、徳永君、やっとまともなゲームがでてきたようだ。

37232370.review:
This game, is probably one of the better RPGs out there. Sure there are many RPGs just like this, but this game is handled perfectly. For other typical RPGs, you just have to simply click a button and wait for your opponent's turn to end. Other have some form of interactive actions that you are needed to do while playing.

But, Kingsway handles this interactive gameplay a lot more.... Interactive..
The quick time events with clicking out of windows to click onto other windows to stop the opponent's attack is genius and I hope to see this function to be implemented to newcoming RPGs. It doesn't have to be windows going across your screen, at least some form if interactivity involved while battling your opponents.

For example, waiting for a bar to be filled before attacking. Or a unique dodging mechanic and counter attacks. Just to add a little twist in a game that just is about fighting goblins, slimes, and skelebones. Kingsway has some of these functions and it makes it what this games is. 
(Yes I know that the old Windows style also plays a huge part to what this game is!)

36795983.review:
This game somehow manages to give the infuritation with a dark souls game while never leaving the nostalgic text based RPG style.
It has a classes and a newly generated world for each different run. With each time you play you get a little bit closer and a bit farther to the end. And as you inch towards the finish line you get to experience new monsters and creatures on your journey. All while leveling and getting skill points and stat points to buff your class.
My only critiques are it's unforgiving difficulty and feeling of getting no progression, as you lose all but one item (of your choice) after dying and have to create an entirely new character just to play again. I've played only a couple runs, but each time i've died I lost hours of progress. You also have to UNLOCK THE KEYBINDS which is just a massive time waster, but that was kind of the point of the game anyway.
If looking for a game to quickly run through and to relax - not recommended. If you are looking for an RPG nostalgia trip - Recommended.

36674484.review:
开头还觉得挺有新意的，渐渐就开始有固定套路了，然后就没有意思了。。。基本上游戏就一个套路：莽。4级之后就是浪。。。

好吧其实这个游戏很符合中世纪奇幻冒险的风格的。但它就像标题一样，太王道了。王道到难以理解的地步。固定的路线，固定的主题，固定的套路。甚至节奏都是固定的。这就让游戏的中后期十分乏味。界面和操纵方式还是有点新意的，但就仅此而已了。

对于新手来说比较好上手吧。

难以理解的是它前期的节奏处理得相当好，甚至可以说完美了。无论是数据的平衡还是其他。能让你有一种我真的在冒险的感觉。堪堪剩下一丝血的时候升级的刺激超棒的。但，4级以后就失衡了。然后boss的强度就莫名的高，但你自身的强度也莫名奇妙的高起来。最后世界上能成为对手的只剩下boss。不知道以后能不能改善。

没有中文，但不妨碍体验游戏。

我的推荐是尽可能降价时买。不过原价入手也是值得的。它的游戏体验很独特，独一无二。不过受不了王道的冒险故事的玩家请回吧。毕竟，人家标题写得这么清楚了。

kingsway，王道。

36457099.review:
Terminé [B]Kingsway[/B] deux fois en 6 heures de jeu (fins 1 et 2). Un [strike]rogue[/strike]lite qui m'a fait un peu penser à [I]Knights of Pen & Paper[/I] dans sa structure : on avance de points en points sur une map vue du dessus, on se tape des combats aléatoires (qui s'expédient assez rapidement) au tour par tour durant les déplacements entre ces points. Le jeu consiste à aller allumer trois flambeaux pour pouvoir accéder au château final et défoncer le boss de fin. C'est très classique et assez simpliste aussi bien pour ce qui est du scénar' que du gameplay ; le jeu se démarque surtout par son interface qui reprend un bureau d'ordinateur dans (sur ?) lequel chaque fenêtre correspond soit à la map, soit à l'inventaire, soit aux statut de notre personnage, etc. ça rajoute un petit truc en combat puisque la fenêtre du combat se déplace sur l'écran (en général pas trop vite) de sorte qu'il est parfois un peu compliqué de cliquer au bon moment sur le bouton d'attaque ou de défense, mais aussi d'aller cliquer dans une autre fenêtre pour utiliser une potion, etc.

L'idée n'est pas mauvaise et donne clairement une identité assez sympa au jeu, mais ça reste de l'ordre du gimmick plutôt que de la vraie bonne idée de gameplay, d'autant que les situations rencontrées en jeu sont assez peu variées et que, contrairement à d'autres "rogue-lite", on ne débloque pas grand chose qui pourrait raviver l'intérêt pour le jeu au fur et à mesure de nos parties. A peine quelques options pour un gift de départ, et des héros avec de nouvelles stats. Par contre tout est très fluide, on avance bien et rapidement (le jeu est même un peu trop simple peut-être) et là où j'avais rapidement laissé tombé [I]Knights of Pen & Paper[/I] parce que j'avais l'impression de devoir grinder bêtement pour pouvoir avancer, ici le jeu se déroule assez naturellement.

En bref, ce n'est peut-être pas le jeu du siècle et n’espérez pas y passer 60 heures, mais c'est tout de même un chouette petit jeu "casual" sur lequel passer 3 à 6 heures (pour ses premières parties) et plus si affinités. Le jeu sauvegarde automatiquement à chaque instant donc on peut facilement le lancer par petites sessions : parfait comme jeu détente ou pour faire une pause entre deux plus "gros" jeux ! 

...

...

...

Oui oui, c'est un jeu que je recommande, on ne dirait pas comme ça hein ? Je suis vraiment un mauvais vendeur... :facepalm:

Enjoyed the game for what it is. Unique in presentation for a bog standard roguelike(almost a roguelite in style). Because of the roguelike mechanics and soft-time limit, I abandoned trying to learn the game as I went and stuck to finding information online on what and how things worked. You will have bad runs until you do some research on what works and what doesn't and the game takes too long (takes me about 2-3 hours on a successful run) for the learning process to be enjoyable. 

The impression I got from the trailers was not how the game felt but stuck with it and had a good time. Definitely not for everyone. Made me wish it was a traditional rpg that was more about puzzle and reactionary gameplay (the popups were incredibly fun but lackings) instead of the simple roguelike that it is.

The game is great in all ways but one: It's a time-limited run game. This is to say there is a mechanic similar to FTL's where a shadow sweeps across the world from left to right forcing you to run ahead of it without exploring everything.

36317235.review:
Kingsway is a roguelike RPG in the style of an old-fashioned computer operating system. This means you'll navigate the world via progress bars, manage your inventory like you would files in folders, get quests as spam e-mails, and fight off enemies that appear as pop-ups. To be honest, the game doesn't really use this gimmick as much more than window dressing — the most interesting gameplay twists are how enemy windows move around during combat, adding a very light annoyance to clicking on battle commands, and how some enemies cast spells that appear as moving pop-ups that can be closed to avoid their effects. 

The depth and challenge the game provides is also a bit sparse. I've beaten the game thrice, each time using a different class, but played them virtually identically by dumping all of my stat points into Strength and all of my skill points into the shared passive Vigilance (first few attacks are faster) and any other passive that would increase the power of my damage and criticals. While there are spells to learn, some unique to each class, you only have five spots on your hotbar you can slot them into, and honestly there's no reason to care when you can instead have your critical attacks stun and leech health at no cost.

Combat in this game is a barebones, normally one-on-one affair that has a typical loop of "get in as many hits as possible, then block before the enemy's attack bar fills all the way up." Of course, if you manage your build like mentioned above and accumulate enough good equipment over your travels — which is easy to do naturally — you'll eventually get to a point where you'll just spam attack at everything and never die. 

To be fair, I haven't tried either of the magic-focused classes, the challenge class that only has one arm, or the unlockable Hard Mode yet, but to say the least you probably won't be putting a lot of care into your decisions like other roguelikes tend to demand. The most pressure the game puts on you is a shadow that slowly envelops the game world from left to right as time goes on, replacing regular enemy encounters with a sole "Shadow" enemy that hits fairly hard but is still easy to kill.

After you successfully finish the game at one of its five endings, you will earn gems you can use to unlock better starting gifts for future runs, as well as some hotkeys and visual customization options. Again, these leave a bit to be desired, as after one run you will probably have enough gems to get your preferred starting item (IMO, the Large Bag), the hotkeys are not actually all that useful, and the customizations are limited to two additional window color themes, some mouse cursors, and making the font uglier or unreadable. It would have been really cool to be able to unlock customization options that dramatically change the look of the game like different game icons or tilesets, or at least complete control over theme colors, but sadly that isn't the case.

In spite of all of my criticisms, I still like Kingsway a lot. Going on a miniature adventure, one without any of the stresses that most roguelikes entail, killing silly-looking monster pop-ups and shoving loot into my bag-folders, all while some cheesy fantasy MIDIs play in the background, is just a nice way to zone out and relax. I'd definitely check this game out if you're into the idea of pleasant, minimalist RPG journeys.

35955927.review:
Kingsway is a pretty fun game. A fairly standard roguelike in a lot of ways, but solidly made.

Gameplay: In terms of raw gameplay, the game is solid. Not the best I've ever played, but it's not bad either. The way enemies 'dodge' your attacks by moving the entire window is strange, but it works well. Many non-combat encounters take the form of short choose-your-own-adventure type sequences. It is a bit shallow in terms of content at the moment, but hopefully there will be updates to fix that in the future. 7.5/10

Music: The music isn't anything that's going to be stuck in your head; no amazing atmosphere like in Bastion. But it's pleasant enough, and is good at evoking the nostalgic feel of old-school gaming. 8/10. Note, you do have to turn the music on manually in game, which is slightly amusing, but I find it a little awkward (although not enough to actually take a point off).

Visuals: It's not super-HD triple A visuals, but the game has a style, and it sticks to it. Everything is neat and tidy, nothing feels overwhelming, and the UI is pretty clean and, due to the theming, highly customizable. 8/10.

Story/Lore: The story is mostly an excuse plot... or at least seems to be at first. It's slightly deeper than it looks, but at the same time, it's not really the game's main draw. Still, while the story and lore aren't necessarily deep, what is there is good enough for a game of this kind. 7/10

Replay Value: This one could go either way. There are a variety of classes and potential builds, as well as multiple endings, so if you don't mind the non-combat events beng a bit same-y, then the replay value is solid. You can think of it sort of like a board game with a limited deck of event cards; you'll see them all eventually, but that doesn't mean you can't keep playing the game. That said, I doubt I'll be playing this game a year from now unless it gets some major updates... but considering the price, I expect I'll get my money's worth. 7/10.

Other notes: The game does have a soft time-limit of sorts, in the form of the Sky Eater's Shadow. There are ways around it, but if time limits bother you, you might want to wait until alternate campaigns are added. Also, while there is a permanent progression system, in the form of using Crystals to unlock new starting bonuses as well as a few other features, it feels a bit like the game was 95% done when someone said 'We should have a permanent progression system'. It sits on top of the game, instead of really being a part of it.

Overall Opinion:

A solid game. You're not going to look back nostalgically on it in 30 years' time, but it'll give you a good few hours of fun. 82/100

[h1] The GUCCI [/h1]
I think this game is certainly worth your money as a well made indie game, its been a looong time since I have played a satisfying RPG like this one. You are well rewarded for beating bosses and dungeons and making choices within the game is fair and legitimate (e.g making a logical choice jump over a pit but cucks you amyway by having a plot dagger tell you your going to fall in anyway and kill you SORCERY 2 AMIRITE?!!) not to say there can be uncertainty and risks depending on your choices.

[h1] What's GUCCI [/h1]
However after completing the game replayability becomes an issue. You see, after achieving one of the multiple endings you essentially have to start over the exact same way with only minor differences in procedural generation (map shape and position of waypoints) and potentially a new class to play. This puts me off personally knowing I will be rexploring the same kind of dungeons and enemies and towns just to branch off late game for a different outcome at the end.

[h1] What's not GUCCI [/h1]
Furthermore there is a problem with the game's balance. The game gets easier the further your progressing which really should be the other way round. I often get a surplus of resources in my inventory like 9 spare high tier healing potions that I never usually need. This will make replayability only more underwhelming understanding the basic concept of the game inside-out due to the lack of varied content.

However that is heavily outweighed by the "true experience you start with" which is certainly satifying. I can garuntee for smart players you will get at least 5-6 hours of unique gameplay before it gets repetitive for the other endings (unless your bad at rpg games consider adding a few more hours LOL). 35472645.review:
I first tried a demo of Kingsway at Indie MEGAbooth, and I fell in love with the idea. I don't normally play RPG's, but I loved the flavor of this game. I was excited to play the full thing.

I started the game, and I found that the 15-minute demo I played was representative of the full game. Like, [i]very[/i] representative. The game never really evolved after the start - throughout the whole game, you're fighting essentially the same monsters with different skins. This wouldn't be a problem if the core gameplay was fun, but for the most part the gameplay was average. I enjoyed avoiding enemy projectiles (which essentially amounted to quick-time events where new windows pop up and you have to close them), but besides that it doesn't really feel that different from other RPG's.

My other problem with the game is its difficulty curve - I beat the game twice, once as a Warrior and another time as the Worthless class, who starts with poor stats and can't hold a shield. Both times, I found that after I reached some threshold around level 8, I pretty much was too strong to die. As long as I didn't fight enemies 3 levels up, it felt like I was able to kill everything by just spamming the basic attack, and I didn't even have to worry about using any of the several potions I've stored in my bag. This problem was only exasperated as you level up, to the point where I just found the endgame tedious, instead of fun. There was absolutely no sense of danger. All the difficulty is just concentrated at the start.

I really wanted to enjoy this game, but I just didn't find myself having fun.

35134132.review:
After 100% Kingsway, I decided to write a review for a game I really liked. For those who do not know, Kingsway is an rogue-lite RPG with the UI of an old windows OS. It's neat. I would like to get this out of the way, I don't get the negative reviews with them expecting more out of the game because of the trailer. All the trailer states is customizable UI and nothing else. I can say the Trailer is a bit vague, but because of the vagueness of it, people projected what the game will be like and overhyped it for themselves. This, of course, disappointed those people. I guess I will start with the pros:

Pros:

Cool Aesthetic

Combat is fun for the most part (Little windows pop up and the enemies move around the screen and you have to defend and attack at the right moments, use spells/abilities, or choose to escape)

Unlockables that make starting the game again easier

Great Soundtrack

Unlike some other people, I actually enjoy the different classes.

Varied enemies as the game progress. Some are pretty interesting, like the Phantom (Who can close your UI windows) or Shadow Bandit (Minimizes his battle window so you have to manually click it open)

Very few bugs


Neutral:

It's fun to get a broken combo of legendary items that give skills that your class usually doesn't get and you are able to cheese your way through some bosses. This is could be seen in two areas.

Cons:

Can get repetitive, however, it depends on the type of person, since I had fun for all the hours I played. The game lacks a lot of events, so events start to repeat. It takes about 2 or 3 playthroughs to see all the events in the game. Events range from quests, dungeon events, and overworld events that give items or buffs.

Some enemies are purely attack and defend, which works for some and not for others. E.G. The sea serpents and goatmen.

In some ways the game is a bit too easy, I usually am able to complete an ending on my first or second try with any class. Once you get past level 10, and you aren't stupid, it pretty much guaranteed that the run is going to be successful. The only class I had to repeat 3 times was the beastkin was because a bug stopped me from getting the "Complete the game as a beastkin" so that was annoying, ending 5 "Sacrifice" is the bugged ending.


Overall: I think it is a solid game and worth a buy. For achievement hunters, it's quite good and for someone who looks for a casual rogue-lite experience, it's also great. If I would give this game a number rating, I would give it either a 8/10 or 9/10.

35080975.review:
Worth the 10 bucks and I'm going to try explaining why through a bad review

1) First of all, the aesthetic for anyone that likes the look of old PC-98(?) or ancient MAC-OS, as the game is a tiny mix of both. I'm stuck on windows 10 because of my specs so that's definitely refreshing.

2) Probably not for everyone, but I got attached to the music after a while. The soundtrack is definitely gonna loop a few times during a full playthrough as that's probably gonna be around 3 hours and the playlist is about 30 minutes long or so. not a musical expert (read: a fuckin idiot) so I don't have much to say about it besides "it's neat.".

3) The pacing of the game. After a few minutes you'll already get what you're going to do in battles for the rest of the game without it becoming too grating, as the different characters and the pop-up attacks from various enemies keep you on your toes. 
Lest you wear the ring of pain, the shadow moves slowly enough for you to grind peacefully on the left-mid side of the map until you're actually ready to move towards the end of the game. Even then, the shadow isn't like in One Way Heroics. It just changes the enemy type from being biome-specific enemies to an ambiguous "shadow" that can be fought and still gives XP, but no items.

Complaints:
If anything, I feel like the quests are lacking. I've seen the game streamed firsthand and I thought the game was going to be absolutely massive and a playthrough would take ages, but despite the map being randomized every playthrough, the quests you get are generally pretty static. There isn't exactly a ton of enemies either, you'll just encounter the Cultists in the mountains, the Clot in the catacombs, stronger variants of previously fought enemies as you go to the right side of the map (with a few original enemies here and there like the goatmen).
Also, a more detailed stats menu showing some of the more auxilary stats (like the magic power boost you get from Warded enchanted items) would be nice.

Overall, trying to get the 5 different endings with a different character each time is how I recommend playing, as you'll probably get the most of your money's worth that way.
(protip: do your first run with the beastman and invest into iron stomach)

35078653.review:
Fun, charming, addictive, great gameplay loop. It probably took me about 15 hours to get fully through the game and to one of its several endings, and that was enough for me to feel satisfied with it.

Pros:
-All the details reminiscent of 90's Windows PCs are charming.
-The gameplay, loot and game economy are like catnip (to put it nicely) for classic RPG fans.
-Combat is just the right balance of challenging and empowering. No obstacle is unsurpassable with the right prep.
-The art is thematically cohesive and imparts a nostalgic feeling.

Cons:
-The game has some bugs. The first time I got very powerful and 80% through the game, when I saved and came back later, the game couldn't load my save without crashing. After that, on my next successful playthrough, I always kept the game running so I didn't have to load a save, just in case.
-The music is meh. On the positive side, this game is perfect for playing while listening to interesting podcasts, so the music isn't needed.

35066918.review:
The game has a somewhat interesting presentation, but the interface felt clunky and the gameplay was not that fun (as warrior class). Beat it on the second try, not going to play again, even though there are other endings to get.

I think what bothered me the most was the combat system. You pick your attack by clicking a button, then a little bar fills, and when it's full you attack. The enemy does the same (minus the button), and of course keeps attacking no matter if you act or not. You have to pick your attack quickly so you don't waste time, and while you are doing that the button actually moves around. I got used to that quickly, so after a while the moving wasn't challenging anymore, just annoying. Also occasionally enemies do special attacks that you can dodge by clicking some other suddenly appearing moving buttons. What it boils down to is that I had to put actual effort into controlling my character. The very opposite of tight controls. Getting your character to do what you want is part of the challenge, and constantly drains your awareness. I like turn based games, and I like action games, but in this weird mix the two components only took away from each other.

Other than that I was mostly annoyed by having to use purely mouse controls for everything (you can actually unlock hotkeys later on, great...). And a bunch of things just felt clunky. For example the inventory. I spent a lot of time dragging little item icons from one window to another, either to loot them or to organize the items. It really does feel like organizing files on an old OS, and you have to do it purely with your mouse. And after every fight you have to click loot, take the loot, then click that you want to continue. It drags on a bit after a while.

The difficulty curve is as you would expect from a casual game with permadeath. If you survive the early game, there is very little risk of dying if you play a beefy character. I was pretty bored by the end.

There are much better roguelikes available that are just as easy to get into and are more fun. Some of them are even free. This is not a bad game, but I wouldn't recommend it.

34987479.review:
What I came in expecting:
"So... some sort of king simulator on an old windows computer? That sounds fun. I guess leading adventurers off to things? I mean it's an Adult Swim Game so I know I'll be expecting a good game. Oh! It's on sale. Might as well grab it now."

This game is not what I was expecting. But it is a amazing RPG roguelike game. Now I normally hate games with time limits. But this game does it so perfectly. You aren't too rushed when you know what you're doing. Although I admit my first playthrough I was like "AH! Darkness! Move move move! *dead*" But after you get the swing of things you will enjoy this game if you enjoy rpgs or roguelike games.

So something I have to point out. It is really hard to get attached to your characters in roguelike games. Most of the time you end up with Rogue Legacy or Dark Souls where you might enjoy a character but you know they are going to get destroyed by something. Now I'm not saying these are both bad games. They are both good games. But with Kingsway, you feel attached to your characters so much. (Especially with the added ability of bringing your own portraits. I'm enjoying ROTK characters roaming or getting rekt by monsters.) Each character you customize the growths and find skill books that can give them skills that might be hard to come by for their classes. Oh yeah their are a total of 8 classes. 3 unlockable ones. And 5 different endings as well. Each really fun and rewarding (except ending 5. Where you just get rekt.)

And a huge huge huge bonus. With the funny unique mechanics they do with the old windows computer set up. They still manage to bring you into the world and have you enjoy all the creatures and the different enviroments.  Whether it's cult of demons or a cult of flying darkness monsters. Each have their own dungeons with a varied amount of different creatures. This game has quite a bit of secrets. And I wouldn't recommend looking up any until you go through your first succesful playthrough.

In conclusion. I recommend this game easily. Although it's different than I was expecting. It certainly wasn't bad. It was amazing. One of the best roguelike rpgs in my opinion. Buy it full price. Or wait for a sale. you'll be getting your money's worth either way.

34981578.review:
If for some reason you feel reminiscent of the Windows 95 OS, you should probably play this game. After Kingsway, I am proud to say that I was lucky enough to be born during a time when Windows 95 reigned supreme. I don’t remember much other than the ridiculously hideous UI with the solid grey taskbar and borders. Playing made me want to change my desktop theme to match it and when I did, I absolutely hated it. Andrew Morrish, creator of Super Puzzle Platformer, and Adult Swim published Kingsway as a means for us to all remember why we hated early Windows OS (Some of us still hate current OS, thanks Microsoft). This rogue-like takes the player into the a fantasy world, where you are trying to save it from a world-eating monster.

Kingsway is the encapsulation of all the best and worst things that the 1990s Windows OS had to offer. In a way the game is simultaneously beautiful and and outright obsolete. The piercing blue screen that you encounter when your character dies reminds me of the blue screen of a stop error when a computer crashes. The ugly grey and blocky borders on the windows is nostalgic with a hint of “Oh God, is this what Windows used to look like.’ It truly captures the essence of what 90s Windows OS used to look and feel like. The fluidity of the OS is unbelievable and accurate to the time that it represents.

Kingsway a reminiscent game of an era that has passed. The look and the feel of the game only add to the experience. Although the game lacks a story, it is made to push the player to try new things. It may take time, but reaching the end is achievable. The gameplay is where the game really shines. It was fun to manage each window that would appear; I enjoyed each individual challenge that every enemy presented. The point-and-click adventure part of the game was secondary to the fluid combat system. Experimenting with classes lead to different outcomes and it felt like I learned something through each character. The generic upgrade system per character death is something found in many other rogue-likes. The atmosphere and the aesthetics of the game really drive it home for me. If you’re looking for a game that reminds you of the Windows OS glory days, this is the perfect one. The game is easy to pick up and play on the go. The controls limit the game to a mouse and keyboard and the only thing I would want more out of this game, is the ability to play it on the go.

For a more details, here is the full review on my website: http://www.pushiforinventory.com/afantasyofwindows

34943571.review:
I am, admittedly, not big on the roguelike genre, especially those designed like operating systems I used 20 years ago, but Kingsway has captured me. This is a good game. A really good game.

Part of the charm is that, like Windows 95, you're basically fighting against the interface as much as you are fighting against your enemies. It'll get cluttered, but that's a good thing. It allows you to easily monitor your stats, equipment, access healing items like potions and keep a log of everything that's happened in a run. Combat is pretty rewarding as well. Since you're fighting against the UI as much as you are enemies, keeping up with the battle and switching between attacking, blocking and healing at regular intervals without dying or losing track of your enemy's attack progress bar in the process feels like a huge accomplishment in of itself. As you gain levels, complete quests (which are given to you via email, by the way; there's even ones that mimic spam emails from 20 years ago!) and boost your stats and reputation as you progress through the game, it truly feels like you're growing from a newbie adventurer into a skilled knight or mage, ready to storm the king's castle.

While the UI can be frustrating if you're a first-time player, the familiarity of an operating system also lets you adapt to Kingsway faster than most other games in this genre. It definitely is an interesting choice, but also probably the best, because by your 4th or 5th run you'll be familiar with how the game works, its quirks and how to make your way through the world.

Oh, and yes, this game can run on a toaster. A computer from 10 years ago, but if you want a computer from 20 years ago that can run it, look at the real Windows 95. Really, if you're still using a Pentium MMX for some reason, get a new computer. Unless you're a retro computing enthusiast like me, you have no excuse.

Overall, I give it a Yes. If you're looking for a fresh take on the roguelike genre without spending too much and with a ton of charm to it, give Kingsway a go. It is the #1 operating system for daily tasks like skeleton smashing and loot organizing, after all, and unlike Windows, it doesn't cost $200 for a license!

34928459.review:
A deceivingly smart RPG, Kingsway grabs you by the throat and just doesn't let you go. You want to get to that castle, and you get awfully attached to your characters, even if they are not meant to be durable at all.

The whole "RPG OS" theme is quite bright. The combat system is really interesting and creative. It's difficult to put in words, but there is something charming and fun about receiving emails from your guild with quests or having to open a minimized window to avoid the sneak attack from an assassin.

There will be a window for your world map, one for your inventory, one for your stats and so on... And then, to beyond your character, monsters will attack you with infection-like pop-up windows and loot will be collected from your enemies folders. The amount of windows opened may also have effect on gameplay: some monsters may open hidden windows behind all of them, with bombs and curses that you have to close before they damage you... But closing all windows is also risky, since some monsters will deal more damage after all windows are closed. In fact, some monsters attack by closing windows you have opened.

The game could really benefit from a little more variety, but for it's price and considering it's not something you are supposed to play for 100h or more, this is not a huge concern, and certainly not reason to dislike the game. I would recommend it quite highly for the concept alone, but since it's quite well done, I think it deserves every good review it can get.

34913056.review:
Kingsway is rogue-lite/like which pits you against a world-ending force all wrapped up in a gimmicky little package - but don't be fooled; gimmicks can be fun! 

Using a Windows 95-esque OS, you'll manage your characters stats, abilities, levels, your inventory - everything, really - and progress through your run. Combat has an interesting pace where certain attacks (such as rocks falling or poison darts soaring towards you) actually posess their own OS window. These windows will move behind your current combat window while also obscuring your stats/inventory windows; and losing track of them can spell your doom! This puts an interesting emphasis on clever window management and actively rewards you for not only having fast reaction time, but also being able to multitask and manage multiple windows at the same time. 

Overall the game is extremely fun and engaging, despite following what at first seems to be a typical turn-based system. The OS gimmick is less of a gimmick and more of a platform upon which to deliver a unique and fresh rogue-like experience.

34844088.review:
I beat the game and watched all the different endings just to be sure I wasn't missing anything.
The game was both good and disappointing.

This is a solid rpg with turn-based-not-turn-based combat and I really liked the mechanics.
The main problem I had with the game was that with the setting of the whole game being an operating system, you'd expect them to do more meta stuff with that. While the game messes with you in cool ways, it never really ties the story with the computer OS mechanic.

They could have easily made the story a lot more interesting if they just had a tiny bit more imagination and were less grounded in their plot, at least towards the end. Huge missed opportunity. Still, it's mechanically a good game, albeit a bit too expensive for its simplistic combat system and lack of really interesting enviroments.

Oh, and if you suck, it'll get repetitive really quickly. In order not to suck though, here is a short list of tips:
-Almost never rest (takes too much time)
-Go through as many nodes in your path as possible
-Visit most dungeons
-Go through all dungeon nodes, if at all possible
-Remember, XP and stats are key to everything

Conclusion:
Basically, I'd say the game is worth around 7 Eur, if you manage to beat it on your fifth try. If you're really bad at turn-based RPGs or clicking on slowly moving small buttons, don't buy it for over three.

Edit:
I recommend games only if I think they're worth it at full price.

34540009.review:
[h1][u]DOES IT PLAY?[/u][/h1]
[b][i]Yes, for those who appreciate the niche experience[/i][/b]

Kingsway was a pleasant surprise. It's simply an RPG where fighting the interface is part of it's gameplay.  While it's standard to say you have multiple classes, permadeath mechanics, Active-time combat and replayability... this game's uniqueness is the interface and how the gameplay engages.  As the horror genre uses interactive mouse to immerse you into the gameplay. The UI manipulation in this game takes simple menu clicking to a wonderful immersion as well.  I found myself engaged to where time disappeared as I played through the game. 

For the price, I believe this game is worth it for me.  I believe at least 60 minutes of gameplay will confirm this for you or not. I also recommend turning on mouse trails in the options for nostalgia.  

[h1][u]DOES IT ENTERTAIN[/u][/h1]
[b][i]The viewers responded well and appreciated how mechanics in the game created chaotic moments I had to respond to.[/i][/b]

This game allows for stop and go pacing. If you aren't actively engaging, the game pauses for you.  Every item in the game can be renamed, including characters, which allows for including your communities into the game.  Alternatively you can name everything buttmunch or other such comical names.  However, the simplicity of the game interface means that the entertainment naturally focuses on you as a broadcaster first and foremost.  This is a especially strong for broadcasters who connect to their communities and hold conversations. 

[h1][u]DOES IT STREAM[/u][/h1]
[b][i]Yes, as it provides varied pacing of activity ranging from "chat with community" to "OMG! CLICK ALL OF THE THINGS!"[/i][/b]

When action is happening there are some unexpected results/twists where you can suddenly find yourself juggling a lot and have natural opportunities to react to the game in very entertaining ways. While a lot of the gameplay elements throughout the game become understanding the underlying systems, it's stream-style feels like Binding of Issac RPG playthroughs where eventually it's about execution and maintaining good conversation with your community.

Bem, vamos começar com o básico:

Kingsway é um jogo que simula um RPG de computador, só que ao pé da letra.

Tudo nesse RPG funciona como se fosse um computador, as Quests que você recebe no decorrer do jogo vem por Email, para abrir a mochila ou o Mapa, você precisa clicar no icone deles na "Area de tabalho", é algo realmente divertido e inovador.

Por mais simples que o jogo pareça ser, ele é TENSO. Quando você começa a enfrentar mais de dois inimigos de uma só vez (isso acontece em batalhas de Boss), ou quando você precisa desviar de algo, você precisa ser mais agil do que seu computador pode captar para administrar tudo. E a pior parte: Se você morre, suas coisas vão junto. Não tem como recupera-las para outro personagem.

Embora eu não tenha muito ido com o preço, eu realmente me diverti bastante nas 3 horas que joguei. Aos poucos ele vai ficando meio chatinho. Os encontros se repetem bastante depois da sua 3 ou 4 vida. Mas se você está disposto a superar isso e desfrutar da quebra de cabeça que você vai passar para equipar certos itens no seu personagem, vá em frente, o jogo é ótimo nisso. Sumemo.

34325257.review:
先说一下大概流程吧。那个黑色的祭坛可以献祭蓝色装备，然后可以加点。开三个小boss点燃三个火焰，会开一个门，打掉boss然后掉一个神级装备，人就基本无敌了。

注意事项是：1.我装备基本不买，都是垃圾。2.看前期地下城遇到地精的话可以补充一下缺的装备，后期就不用买了，都是废物。3.哪儿有个地方可以献血..等你献祭血到个位数时会跳出来一个恶魔收拾你（然后我一个火球过去他就没了=。=）。4.个密码房，旁边有画，画上有人，人数就是答案。5.S在城里面能买药就买药，有药在boss面前就是爸爸。6.B城里有储物箱，可以保存东西，任务道具什么的都可以放在里边，像前期的头骨什么的，很占背包。7.转召唤的小怪如果3下能解决掉就解决，不行就打召唤师，召唤师的攻击挺疼的，最好防御一下。8.我有一个饰品是加三围属性的，有个debuff一定要带上，这样就能一直碰到恶魔，然后刷等级了:)。9.测背包有就买，不嫌多，记得把药瓶放在两个不同的背包里，小心怪物使诈，或者直接点属性拖到旁边备用。10.评价一下赶路，赶路的时候穿上旅行套装，就是加旅行速度的那些，然后疯狂逃跑吧（时间就是金钱我的朋友）。11.不用太赶时间，状态不好可以睡觉，因为左边的雾霾其实没有想象中的快。12.注意如果要买东西的话还是买个大背包吧，快捷键没有卵用。13.明着告诉你法爷可以给普通装备附魔，其他角色普通装备就丢了吧，太重。13.出来后前期建议选盗贼稍微刷一下，可以点一个开箱的技能，刷到史诗级武器之后，随便找个地方死一死一，看是什么职业的装备，然后继承遗产（一定要带在死者身上）。14.处理开出来的书很关键，有的技能极强，是真的强，无敌的那种，有的...烧了吧。15.哼开始的技能都比较废柴，等级升上去以后会有新的技能刷出来，主动技能一两个就够了，后期有强力技能书，建议多学一点被动


以下是评价：这游戏给人的第一印象是与众不同，不论是游戏界面，战斗方式，还是... ...都让人耳目一新。为什么“还是”两个字后有六个点点？因为我写到那里愣了好久，然后发现，实在没有什么其他的优势可言了。一共玩了五个多小时，尝试了战士，法爷和盗贼，刚开始上手还比较容易死，因为对技能，游戏特性和物品装备都不熟，但是到了后面，玩了大概2小时，整个游戏就开始变得无聊了，所有的怪物和实践都是一直在重复，除了血多一点。不管用什么角色，就是刷本，回城，刷本，回城...然后无限循环。偶尔有一两个任务，一两个野生boss，再稍微发育一下后也弱的不堪一击，打个比方，我用的法爷，一个技能甩过去（伤害是智力*系数），没了？，后面的boss什么的也是，随便磕两个药，搓技能，没了？主线流程也没什么自由度，玩一遍基本上所有剧情和事件就都清楚了，然后就是尝试一下不同的角色，看看有什么技能。

不过总的来说，这个游戏还是很有新意的，音乐也还凑合，但是自由度和可玩性不高。给作者的新意点一个赞，但是值不值得买？买个情怀吧。我看哪个智障转我测评不注明出处？

Весьма минималистичная, но от того ничуть не менее интересная игра. Можно назвать её текстовой RPG, отличающейся необычным графическим интерфейсом. Уклонение от различных ядов, проклятий и ловушек происходит через этот же интерфейс, создающий различные движущиеся окна. Движутся так же окна врагов, перекрываются друг другом и творят прочие разные вещи, в зависимости от способностей противников.
Противников множество и делятся они, в основном, на четыре разных группы. Квестов не так много и, через несколько прохождений, они начинают очень часто повторяться, равно как и рандомные энкаунтеры на локациях и при переходах. В самом начале игры доступно несколько классов, по мере прохождения игры открываются другим классы и стартовые "бонусные" предметы, стили интерфейса и хоткеи.
Сюжет незамысловат, но весьма нелинеен, а мир игры таит множество тайн, ждущих решения. Несколько концовок и стилей игры позволят вам создать своего Героя или Злодея. Спасёте ли вы свой мир от SkyEater'а?

Любителей жанра игра сможет увлечь на несколько вечеров, в отдельных случаях - дней. Всем остальным - просто желательно для ознакомления.

34262481.review:
For its full price-point of ten dollars, I would say that Kingsway does deserve your money.
It is no exaggeration for me to say that this is one of two games I have ever bothered to get all the achievements in, speaking volumes for my short attention span's interest in this particular game, which held its ground for a solid 25 hours before I finally beat the game with all endings, all classes, saw every monster and beat every boss and decided that I had, at long last, seen everything and would no longer find anything else different.
The combat system is new and unique, fresh and fun while proving that fully mastering the art of window management can be unexpectedly difficult.  The soundtrack is one of the best I've heard, probably being the foremost reason I have for staying with the game until the end, as it makes you feel exactly like a harsh journey to save the world ought to.

There isn't a ton of content as runs are fairly short, but there is enough randomization and quality of the base content itself (I personally feel) to justify the price.  My personal biggest disappointment is the endings -- they are very much as basic as can possibly be and don't really do anything to give you or your character some closure, although the puzzle with the monoliths and arch makes me wonder if perhaps there will be more lore or a new game in the works eventually.

If you are not into roguelikes or desire games with high amounts of story, then I cannot in good conscience recommend Kingsway.  (But in good conscience, I highly recommend that you check out the soundtrack anyway.)
If you like roguelikes, Kingsway is a great new addition to the genre and deserves at least a once-over.

34196378.review: A roguelike RPG that is controlled entirely through a fake Windows 95 style operating system.  This game would stand on its own as a fun RPG even without the twist of existing in a fake desktop, but the game makes full use of its fake OS to take the game to the next level.  Towns are early-internet-style web-pages, quests are delivered by email, inventory is a folder system, fights take place in a chat window, and special attacks take the form of moving popups which you have to quickly close to avoid taking the hit.  Even all the music in the game is controlled though a little music player.  While the fake OS could have easily been just a gimmick, it is instead a clever thematic device which permeates every aspect of the game in really interesting ways.

34136727.review: This game is a work of art, genius wrapped in a bundle of originality... however, at its current state, I cannot full-heartedly recommend it. One major flaw, and possible the only flaw, is the lack of variety... which is a bad thing for a randomly generated game. Looking at the screenshots and videos of this game, you'll see "nodes" connecting each line, which I will refer to as "destinations". Upon reaching a destination in the overworld, you are given a "random" encounter - by which I mean, barely random. A majority of the time you will run into an abandoned house/building that has 1-2 monsters in it and virtually nothing else of actual value. Sometimes you'll run into a band of thieves, usually 3 at a time. Other times you will run into a random adventurer or wanderer, who may or may not be under attack from a monster and if you save them, you get an item. Let's not forget our little demon/goblin friend who carries stuff with him and sells you an item from his collection, but only one item, for 50 gold. That's the general scope of the "randomness" of events or encounters in destinations on the overworld. As for maps inside areas, such as a cave, there are no events on any of the nodes. There's just... not enough to this game's encounters/events for it to be worth $10. Perhaps $5, yes, but $10 is just not worth it at this time. Whether or not more encounters/events are planned for the future, I don't know... but I can hope. As a side note, if you do buy this game, then go Rogue. Beat the game on my first ever attempt as Rogue Class and got 153 gems... you'll find out what those are used for later. Rogues are busted...

34108188.review:
Underneath the unique asthetic of an early windows operating system is a surprising deep, challenging and enjoyable rogue-like RPG.

I want to get some details out in front that I was confused by when I first bought the game: While the trappings of the game look like a 'sim' or 'management' game, it's actually a straight-forward, single-character RPG with what ammounts to an early Final Fantasy active-time battle system. It is also indeed a rogue-like, where you'll be dying a lot. BUT, if you have issues with rogue-likes (as I sometimes do), this game is WAY less unfair, and every playthrough has a decent chance of completing the game.

The game's RPG trappings are simplistic but very well done. Explorer-like windows act as your item bags, status, and world map, and your quest looks like Outlook or other old email clients. This aesthetic is cute and doesn't wear out its welcome due to it being very functional and easy to use. The window system plays into the combat as well, as some enemy attacks appear as windows scrolling across the screen that you must click on to avoid, which is easier said than done as other windows may have priority.

Speaking of combat, this is actually one of the best single-character RPG battle systems I've experienced. Your turn and the enemy turn are represented by an increasing progress bar. Some of your actions are faster than others, and the goal is often to get in as many attacks as you can and then switch on your Block action before the enemy turn comes up. This creates all sorts of strategy, and makes high-speed, agility builds viable, as you can get in many attacks before the enemy turn comes up.

There are a wide variety of classes too. While you control which stat to increase, meaning you can turn your character into pretty much whatever you want, the abilities you gain and pick from is dependent on your starting class. This gives you a lot of freedom in how you want to build your character, while also making each new class you pick a different experience. You can also find items that each give you cross-class skills (Like, Fireball or Sword Mastery) when you equip them, or skill books that permenantly give you such skills. Each ending to the game unlocks a new class as well.

The game is a rogue-like, which mean death comes swift and awesome, but as I stated above, it isn't as nasty as other rogue-likes. Once you learn the ins-and-outs of how the game works, a good handle on how to use a given class and know where to go to get signifigant upgrades, victory comes much more commonly than say, FTL, Rogue Legacy or Nuclear Throne and the like. Getting defeated though nets you gems you can spend on more powerful starting gifts for your next characters, and you get the option of taking one item from your dead character to use a gift to the next. Though, I feel there are only a few really useful starting gifts. Lastly, there is a time limit in the form an approaching shadow that covers the land as time passes. But this limit is not as crippling as the similar-acting Rebel Fleet in FTL, as it did not impair most of my playthroughs. Areas covered by the shadow will force you fight an increasingly powerful foe. If your quick and know what you're doing, we can survive and get back out of the shadow, or make your destination before it overcomes you.

Lastly, being a rogue-like, the story is sparse and told only in snipits. At first, it's fairly standard fantasy-fair, but it has many moments of surprising nueance. The endings, while short, are occassionally surprising, and even profound, and not at all what I expected. They often repaint your entire perception of the game.

I cannot recommend Kingsway enough. It's addicting fun, and it's both a properly challenging Rogue-like, while also being quite fair in giving you a chance to win once you learn its secrets. Come for the funny, nostalgic Windows 95 shell, stay for the engrossing RPG.

33983978.review:
[h1]Basic Game Description: Rogue-lite RPG, 1 player[/h1]

[i]+ Pros +[/i]

* Easy to RP in with flexible classes and custom portraits, plus text-heavy events
* Wonderful retro OS presentation
* Dexterity-based battles make the game go beyond "Get Buff, Slay Monsters"

[i]+ Neutral +[/i]

* Incredibly easy for a rogue-lite
* Runs are longer than most rogue-lites.
* Reminiscent of FTL, with node-based maps and real-time combat

[i]+ Cons +[/i]

* Feels like most content is seen within 1-2 good runs
* A single map type, making it get old rather quickly
* Doesn't save you window locations across runs or saves
* Unable to import custom music to match your character, despite the soundtrack being raw OGG files
* No Steam Cloud

Don't get me wrong, Kingsway is a great game and I'm happy to have spent $10 on it. So far I've been an otter wizard and Frog from Chrono Trigger. That's in 10 hours of gameplay, across about 5 runs. A majority of this time was spent as Otto the wizard, who made it to the end on my 3rd run. Compare that to FTL, where I've made the final boss maybe 10 times out of hundreds of runs, and you can see where the game's charm could wear off pretty quickly. It might have a hard mode or something to make the game more challenging, and there are always different classes and characters and builds to try to liven things up, but Kingsway does come off as incredibly easy and front-loaded for the genre. Not necessarily a bad thing, but something to beware of if you're hard-core into rogue-lites.

Add in a few more map types (even if only cosmetic), and a little more enemy and event variety, and you'd have a game that I could heartily recommend for full price. As it stands, I'd suggest at least giving it consideration, but maybe wait for a sale if you're worried about the game running its course rather quickly.  Don't let the longer Cons list above turn you off, all are minor gripes that can be looked past, leaving plenty of fun to be had with Kingsway.

33966552.review:
So, as someone that's utterly loathed Microsoft's infernal OS for years now, imagine my delight when I saw a game that is effectively you VS a Windows-style OS.   The chance to STAB WINDOWS.  Yes. Yes, I wanted that.  Many things could do with a good stabbing in my opinion, but Windows more than most.

And the OS aspect of the game is indeed it's prime focus.  Harking back to the glory days of Windows 3.1 or 95 (whichever you think it looks like most), the interface is what governs every aspect of the game.  But it is also what creates a huge amount of the challenge.  Everything from inventory management to combat involves about a bazillion windows, and managing the desktop-related chaos is part of what the game is about.

The most chaotic aspect though is also the bit that is the most unique:  The game's combat.  Monsters appear, random battle style, whenever you are in the process of travelling from one location to another on the map.  More specifically, they appear as popup windows, because who doesnt hate popup windows?  But these arent normal annoying popups: These are popups that roam around the screen.  These enemy windows constantly move like that in various patterns depending on the enemy, which can make clicking the right buttons difficult.  Your basic actions are to attack or block.  Both enemy attacks and your own have seperate progress bars, and watching the enemy bar to know if you have time to attack, or time to use your shield (which is a toggle, actually, and complicates things) is important.  And more complicated to deal with than you might think.  You can also have two activated spells/skills equipped at any one time.  The basics of combat showcase a big part of the challenge of the game: mouse dexterity.  With these windows constantly roaming, clicking the right buttons with the right timing can be hard, particularly when they are moving fast.

And this is a theme that will show up in all sorts of ways.  The game isnt content with just the whole attack/block thing.  You've got way more to deal with than just that.  Monster special abilities for instance are unique things.  A skeleton mage for instance might have a fireball attack.  In a normal game, it would simply deal damage to you or miss based on math.  In this game, it takes the form of a big window, moving in a fast arc across the screen, with an "AVOID" button on it.  Click the button to not be on fire.  Or it might throw the even more irritating "wobbly curse" window at you, or... all sorts of other things.  Basic attacks, even can have funky effects.  There are enemies that, when they hit you, have a chance at randomly minimizing one of the windows that you have open, which is just as obnoxious as it sounds.  Having your inventory window suddenly close itself just when you were about to click that crucial potion is just nasty.  And what's more, multiple enemies can appear at once, creating utter bloody chaos.  Enemies can even summon MORE monsters, or do things like split into smaller foes, or.... you get the picture.  There's alot going on with the combat here.  It's fun and visceral in it's own very unique way, and induces a special sort of panic that few games ever manage to pull off.

The game is about way more than just combat though.  A big part of the game is about managing your inventory and equipment.  You'll come across all sorts of weapons and items and things, and building your character is just as important and complicated as it is in many roguelikes.  Figuring out which things to equip is not an easy task, nor is choosing what stats or skills to level up.  What's more, you can only hold so many items in any given equipment bag/window, depending on how much different things weigh.  This means for alot of careful decision making, which the game is quite good at.  There is also the travelling and exploring.  You have a big worldmap to wander around, with FTL-style waypoints and routes. When travelling between two waypoints you will get a progress bar (because of course you will), and this is when enemies have the opportunity to pop up, and when traps can be sprung (in dungeons).  The exploration aspect is very well done.  The map is huge and complicated, with all sorts of interesting locations and events.  And unlike FTL, you arent as restricted in your movement.  You dont HAVE to obsessively just move to the right all the freaking time.  Yes, there is a "timer" of the same sort that FTL used, in the form of a foul darkness that slowly comes from the left side, covering the map as it goes.  But "slowly" is the key word here.  You really do have plenty of time for exploration, and backtracking when you see the need.  But you wont be able to explore everything.  Dungeons though are a different story.  Time passes much, much slower in dungeons than on the world map, so explore to your heart's content.  Or try to, anyway... dungeons are more than a little murderous, filled with traps and extra-horrible monsters, and big nasty bosses that'll be flinging windows of doom at you.

During your travels you will also encounter special things that arent just about the map or combat.  You'll find towns and guild buildings, filled with shops and whatnot, you'll find special events and encounters, where you are given an array of choices to make, with different consequences for each.  And you have quests (which take the form of emails, which are often rather goofy) that you can do, which are usually optional, but generally well worth doing if you can pull them off.  There are lots of things to find and do here.

However, the game's content is a bit limited.  It's been criticised often for just not having quite enough... though to be honest it seems fine to me.  But I still think it's worth mentioning.  And while the challenge level is high, it's not THAT bloody hard, so it may not take you long to complete it.

There is stuff to unlock, some of which takes the form of items that you can choose to start with, and other bits that are more Windows-ish, in the form of things like desktop color schemes or mouse cursors, or even hotkeys.  But the list of unlocks is oddly small.  There are also daily runs, but I think a single run is a bit on the long side for this to be truly viable to many players.  It's not the sort of game where I personally would really get into the idea of doing daily runs frequently.  And the biggest issue:  Your screen size. If you are using a monitor that is too small, all those windows are going to get very, very cramped, leading to big problems as you go.  While I havent had this problem myself, I have seen it from others, and it can be a gamebreaker.  

Overall, this is a very challenging and unique game, with a style all it's own, using mechanics that just arent seen anywhere else.  It's not for everyone... the "accurate clicking" based combat may be a big turnoff for some players, which is understandable.  But it has the potential for big fun.  Content also seems a bit low to many, but there is plenty of room here for all sorts of additions, whether it be more monsters or items or whatever.  I'm really hoping to see some cool updates come at some point.   Fantastic game with solid, if bizarre, mechanics.  

And really, screw Windows.  No, no specific joke here, I just wanted to say that.

33917807.review:
I hope I can later change this to a recommendation, but at the moment I just can't recommend the game. I really wanted to like it and bought it on the spot - it looks like a great concept. Unfortunately, while nods and references to the days of Windows 3.1 are appreciated, the game also brings over a lot of the relatively poor UI/UX from those days. At times it feels intentionally-obtuse, making you go through annoying micro-managing, or losing gear you literally just bought if you close the window before you put it in your inventory. To me the straw that broke the camel's back was when I found out that you can eventually unlock shortcut keys. As in, this user-friendly features are locked until you grind to buy them.

Combat in the game is pretty decent, with a good sense of panic conveyed through the overlaying windows of enemies and occasional timing/skill-based defense. That said, it feels pretty flat as combat, with only a few skills available at a time for your solo hero. 

Traveling and towns on the other hand felt pretty sterile, failing to really draw me in and largely seeming monotonous even early on. 

There are some good ideas here and a cool aesthetic for those who have fond (or even not-fond) memories of pre-Windows 95, but as a game it just ended up feeling more like work than fun.

33899106.review:
Hands down one of the most simple, yet creative, RPG's that I have played in a long time. While it doesn't have an in depth story the games combat, character building, and exploration is extremely rewarding the more and more you play. It is quite addicting and character building is completely in the players hands. Classes in this game such as mages and warriors are merely starting templates and the game allows the player to dabble in magic spells and agility weapons even if they chose a warrior. Classes do outline a general idea of what abilities the player can obtain, however a player can easily gain access to various other abilities, both active and passive, through tomes and random encounters. 
Dungeon crawling is the bread and butter as it encourages the player to explore crypts and caves in search of items with randomly generated stats and attributes that pays homage to Diablo 2's loot system. Random encounters are always fun and engaging, allowing the player to decide how they approach a stranger in the woods or perhaps a gang of bandits. The game even has treasure demons that function similar to treasure goblins in Diablo 3.
When creating your first couple of characters, expect them to meet untimely demises as understanding the mechanics of the game are somewhat part of the initial challenge and overall enjoyment. Everything in the world is randomly generated, from dungeon locations, inns, towns, random encounters, and quests.
The quests in this game are given to the player at random intervals and often times have them completing seemingly random objectives throughout the world. They are extremely rewarding and grants the player a heafty sum of experience points and most of the time you are also rewarded with useful potions or equipment.
One of the strongest aspects of the game is that it forces the player to utilize the resources and equipment that they have obtained in an efficient manner that compliments how they build their character. Often times you will be saving items that give you an edge over certain types of enemies for future encounters or dungeon crawling. 
With that said, this mere 10$ game has my praise. You really can't get much more value out of your money and I would highly reccommend that people at least try the game. A little trail and error reveals all when initially beginning the game and don't hesitate to experiment with different items and character builds. But most importantly of all, use your "Dark Blade" if you ever obtain one =)

33897768.review:
Kingsway is maybe the best game game I've played all of 2017. It may not be the most compelling or interesting game on the market, but damn, can it keep me coming back. A run in Kingsway takes at most a couple hours from what I've seen, and there are 5 endings. It has loot of all kinds, many classes, and a diverse cast of villans. Some of the encounters can get repetitive: give a guy a potion, drink from a well, see a monolith. Some of the quests you'll see many times. The difference is every run really feels different. Some runs you're looted to the teeth. other runs you're scrambling for an upgrade. I haven't beaten the game yet, or even completed a single run, but I'm so invested in it.

I really love this game.

If you don't like desktop management, this isn't the game for you.
